G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the acts and omissions giving rise to this action occurred in Lowell, Massachusetts, and the Defendant operates a place of business in this judicial district.

_Mounsey v. Ellard_, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner or business operator owes a duty of reasonable care to those lawfully present on its premises, as stated in _Mounsey v. Ellard_, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).
_Mounsey v. Ellard_, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the landmark Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and holding that an occupier owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. The quoted passage is only a concurrence and focuses on how to treat trespassers, but the majority opinion clearly adopts a general duty of reasonable care to those lawfully on the premises. Thus, the case is accurately cited for the stated proposition, even though the excerpt provided is not the core holding text.
_Mounsey v. Ellard_, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: “We therefore hold that the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees are abolished in this Commonwealth. In their place we impose on the occupier of land a single duty of reasonable care in all the circumstances to all lawful visitors.”

_Poirier v. Plymouth_, 374 Mass. 206, 21.proposition: It was reasonably foreseeable that heavy boxes stored on shelves without adequate stabilization could fall and cause injury to customers.
_Poirier v. Plymouth_, 374 Mass. 206, 21.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt deals only with appellate procedure and the “hidden defect” rule as a general premises-liability doctrine. It does not mention shelves, boxes, storage practices, or foreseeability of falling objects injuring customers. Without any discussion of those facts or that specific foreseeability analysis, this case does not support the claimed proposition.
_Poirier v. Plymouth_, 374 Mass. 206, 21.relevant_excerpt: This action was tried by the parties and submitted to the jury on the plaintiff’s claim that he was injured by reason of a hidden or concealed defect on the defendant’s premises, of which defect the defendant was aware or should have been aware through the exercise of reasonable care. The jury returned a substantial verdict for the plaintiff. The defendant appealed, contending that there was insufficient evidence to support the verdict.

G.L. c. 93A.proposition: Defendant’s failure to take reasonable steps to prevent the danger constituted negligence per se, as it violated both common-law standards of care and the Massachusetts Consumer Protection Act, G.L. c. 93A.

_Ulwick v. DeChristopher_, 411 Mass. 401.proposition: Defendant’s failure to take reasonable steps to prevent the danger constituted negligence per se, as it violated both common-law standards of care and the Massachusetts Consumer Protection Act, G.L. c. 93A.
_Ulwick v. DeChristopher_, 411 Mass. 401.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly rejects the idea that statutory violations here create negligence per se or an independent tort duty. The court reiterates that in Massachusetts violation of a statute, including the criminal alcohol statutes invoked, "does not by itself establish a breach of duty" and does not create a cause of action where no common-law duty exists. It does not discuss G.L. c. 93A at all, and instead affirms that liability must be grounded in common-law negligence, not negligence per se based on statutory violations.
_Ulwick v. DeChristopher_, 411 Mass. 401.relevant_excerpt: "Violations of these statutes invoke criminal penalties, but the statutes do not expressly or implicitly grant an independent ground for civil liability... 'Any liability on the defendant's part in such a situation must be grounded in the common law of negligence... It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se.'... Since no common law duty exists here, it follows that the statutes relied on by the plaintiff do not of themselves create a cause of action in tort."

_Papadopoulos v. Target Corp._, 457 Mass.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries, losses, and damages were directly and proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, as described in _Papadopoulos v. Target Corp._, 457 Mass. 368 (2010).
_Papadopoulos v. Target Corp._, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: Papadopoulos addresses the standard of care for landowners in snow-and-ice slip‑and‑fall cases, abolishing the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction and substituting a general reasonable-care duty. It does not hold or state that the plaintiff’s injuries in that case—or in any case—were ‘directly and proximately caused’ by the defendant’s negligence; indeed, the SJC merely vacated summary judgment and remanded for reconsideration, leaving causation and negligence to be determined. Thus, the opinion does not provide authority for the specific causation proposition asserted.
_Papadopoulos v. Target Corp._, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Because we now abolish the distinction between the natural and unnatural accumulation of snow and ice, and because we apply the premises liability standard of reasonable care retroactively to injuries from slips and falls arising from accumulations of snow and ice, we vacate the allowance of summary judgment in favor of the defendants, and remand the case to the Superior Court for reconsideration of the defendants’ motion for summary judgment in light of this opinion.”
